column10: After stopping at Great Falls Street, I proceeded into the crosswalk. A school bus in the far lane made no attempt to yield to me (and my daughter) in the crosswalk or a pedestrian crossing from the other side. Most cars slow down at this crossing to ensure they yield to bicyclists and walkers. Some, including this school bus, barrel on through even if people are actively in the intersection.
column21: Stop signs on the W&OD are confusing. Most pedestrians and bicyclists ignore them, contrary to City Ordinance for Falls Church (pedestrians) and City and State Law (for bicyclists). Most drivers treat these crosswalks as YIELD or STOP signs, slowing or stopping even before someone enters the crosswalk. Behavior does not match the signage, leading to confusion and danger when someone behaves atypically (e.g., a bicyclist actually stopping at the stop sign or a bus not slowing down when approaching the crosswalk).

column10: A motorist with the license plate VUM2670 honked and passed too closely, within about a foot of my bicycle, while passing me. It was too close, unsafe and unlawful. This was on Great Falls St, heading from Lincoln to West St.
column26: 603 W Falls Way, Falls Church, VA 22046
column34: from a Bike Falls Church newsletter
